title: Judge refuses to release distressing footage of terrorists stalking Federation Square
text:
A judge has refused to release 'distressing' footage of four ISIS fanatics scoping out a location for a terror attack because it could upset parents.

Ahmed Mohamed, 27, Abdullah Chaarani, 29, Hamza Abbas, 24, and his 25-year-old brother Ibrahim planned a terror attack in Melbourne for Christmas Day 2016.

The men wanted to use homemade bombs and knives to kill people in Federation Square, Flinders Street Station and St Paul's Cathedral - but police caught them days before.

Footage (pictured) has emerged of Ahmed Mohamed, Abdullah Chaarani and Hamza Abbas shopping for bomb-making supplies in Broadmeadows on December 21, 2016

At Chaarani's pre-sentence hearing on Wednesday, Victoria's Supreme Court was shown footage of three of the men buying a machete and bomb materials including 700 nail gun cartridges from Bunnings.

But Justice Christopher Beale refused to release footage of the terrorists walking around Federation Square because it would be distressing to the public.

The footage shows the men scoping out the area filled with tourists and families as they worked out how to cause as much damage as possible.

Explaining his decision to keep it secret, Justice Beale said: 'For some people, it might be distressing, to say the least, to see broadcast over the media footage of them near the accused men, for instance, at Federation Square when, on the prosecution case, they're plotting mass slaughter.

Ibrahim Abbas (pictured in October 2018) pleaded guilty and was jailed for 24 years

Mohamed (left in July 2019) was found guilty of preparing a terror attack. Right: Hamza Abbas

'What comes to mind immediately is a little girl playing in Federation Square next to her mother or some adult who's supervising her and sitting very close to the four men chatting.'

Mohamed, Chaarani and Hamza Abbas pleaded not guilty to preparing a terror attack but were convicted by a Supreme Court jury in November 2018.

They will be sentenced on November 29.

Ibrahim Abbas pleaded guilty and was jailed for 24 years.

Chaarani (pictured), a twice-convicted terrorist, said he is disgusted by his part in a plot
description: Ahmed Mohamed, 27, Abdullah Chaarani, 29, Hamza Abbas, 24, and his 25-year-old brother Ibrahim planned a terror attack in Melbourne for Christmas Day 2016.
authors: Charlie Moore For Daily Mail Australia
